expanded_description: Power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred—how quickly energy changes from one form to another. Understanding power connects work and energy (quantities measured in joules) to time, revealing how fast processes occur and enabling analysis of engines, machines, and energy systems.

core_concept.principle: Power is the rate of doing work or transferring energy: $P = \frac{W}{t}$ (average power) or $P = \frac{E}{t}$ (energy transfer rate) where $W$ is work (J), $E$ is energy (J), and $t$ is time (s). SI unit: watt (W), where 1 W = 1 J/s. Instantaneous power for constant force: $P = Fv$ where $F$ is force magnitude and $v$ is velocity in the force's direction.
core_concept.explanation: Work and energy tell us *how much* energy is transferred or transformed—measured in joules. Power tells us *how fast* this transfer occurs—measured in watts (joules per second). Two machines might do the same work (lift same mass same height), but one does it faster—that machine has more power. High power means rapid energy transfer; low power means slow transfer. Example: Lifting 100 kg to 10 m height requires ~9800 J of work regardless of time. Person taking 60 seconds: power = 9800/60 ≈ 163 W. Crane taking 5 seconds: power = 9800/5 = 1960 W. Same work, very different power. Power is crucial for: (1) Rating machines and engines—car engines rated in horsepower or kilowatts (power output). (2) Electricity consumption—electrical devices rated in watts (power consumed). Electric bill based on energy (kilowatt-hours = power × time). (3) Athletic performance—sprinters have high power output (rapid energy conversion), marathon runners sustain lower power longer. (4) Engineering design—must ensure systems can deliver required power, not just total energy. The relationship $P = Fv$ (for constant force) connects power to mechanics: $P = \frac{W}{t} = \frac{Fd}{t} = F \cdot \frac{d}{t} = Fv$. Tells us: For same power, higher speed requires less force (or vice versa). Vehicle climbing hill slowly: low speed, can use lower gear (higher force, lower speed, same power). Accelerating on highway: high speed requires large force to maintain high power. Power determines performance limits: Maximum power available constrains how fast work can be done. Car engine's maximum power limits acceleration capability and top speed (at top speed, engine power exactly balances air resistance power drain).

sections.introduction: Power quantifies how quickly work is done or energy is transformed, distinguishing fast processes from slow ones with the same total energy transfer.

key_concept.definition: Power is the rate of doing work or transferring energy: Average power: $P_{\text{avg}} = \frac{W}{\Delta t} = \frac{\Delta E}{\Delta t}$ where $W$ is work done (J), $\Delta E$ is energy transferred (J), $\Delta t$ is time interval (s). Instantaneous power: $P = \frac{dW}{dt}$ (calculus—rate at instant). For constant force and velocity: $P = Fv\cos\theta$ where $\theta$ is angle between force and velocity. If force parallel to velocity: $P = Fv$.
key_concept.context: Power is everywhere in daily life—watt ratings on light bulbs, horsepower in car engines, kilowatt-hour charges on electric bills. All describe energy transfer rates.

principles.statement: Average power equals work divided by time: $P = \frac{W}{t}$. More work in same time → higher power. Same work in less time → higher power.
principles.application: Calculate power from work and time, or find time needed given power and work.
principles.example: Lift 50 kg mass (weight ~490 N) to 5 m height: Work: $W = mgh = 490 × 5 = 2450$ J. If takes 10 seconds: $P = 2450/10 = 245$ W. If takes 2 seconds: $P = 2450/2 = 1225$ W. Same work, faster time = higher power.

principles.statement: SI unit of power is watt (W): 1 W = 1 J/s (one joule per second). Common multiples: 1 kilowatt (kW) = 1000 W, 1 megawatt (MW) = 10⁶ W, 1 gigawatt (GW) = 10⁹ W. Non-SI: horsepower (hp) ≈ 746 W (still used for engines).
principles.application: Convert between units as needed. Use appropriate scale (W for small devices, kW for homes/cars, MW for power plants).
principles.example: 100 W light bulb: Uses 100 J every second. 1500 W hair dryer: 1.5 kW, uses 1500 J/s. Car engine rated 150 hp: $150 × 746 ≈ 112$ kW. Power plant: 1000 MW = 1 GW (billion watts).

principles.statement: Power equals energy transfer rate: $P = \frac{E}{t}$ or $E = Pt$ (energy = power × time). Energy consumed/produced = power × duration.
principles.application: Calculate energy from power and time. Electrical energy often measured in kilowatt-hours (kWh).
principles.example: 100 W bulb for 10 hours: $E = Pt = 100 × (10 × 3600) = 3,600,000$ J = 3.6 MJ. Or: $E = 100\text{ W} × 10\text{ h} = 1$ kWh (kilowatt-hour = 1000 W for 1 hour = 3.6 MJ). Electric bill charges per kWh.

principles.principle: Power from Force and Velocity: P = Fv
principles.statement: For constant force $F$ acting on object moving at constant velocity $v$ in force direction: $P = Fv$. Derives from $P = W/t = Fd/t = F(d/t) = Fv$. Higher force or higher velocity → higher power.
principles.application: Calculate power when force and velocity known. Useful for vehicles, machines in steady operation.
principles.example: Car moving at 30 m/s against 500 N air resistance: Power needed to overcome air resistance: $P = Fv = 500 × 30 = 15,000$ W = 15 kW. Cyclist pedaling 10 m/s against 40 N drag: $P = 40 × 10 = 400$ W.

principles.statement: Average power: Total work divided by total time. Useful for overall performance. Instantaneous power: Power at specific instant. Can vary throughout process. For variable force/velocity, instantaneous $P = F(t) \cdot v(t)$ varies with time.
principles.application: Average power for rating devices (average consumption/output). Instantaneous for analyzing peak demands, varying loads.
principles.example: Sprinter accelerating: Power varies (high at start—large force, increasing during race—force decreases but velocity increases). Peak power (maximum during race) much higher than average power. Engine at varying speeds: Power changes with RPM and load. Peak power (maximum capability) vs sustained power (continuous operation level).

worked_examples.title: Calculating Power from Work and Time
worked_examples.problem: A motor does 15,000 J of work in 25 seconds. What is its average power output?
worked_examples.concept_applied: Power is rate of doing work: $P = W/t$. More work in less time = higher power.

worked_examples.title: Finding Time from Power and Work
worked_examples.problem: A 2 kW electric heater must deliver 7.2 MJ of heat energy. How long must it run?

step_by_step.explanation: Power: $P = 2$ kW = 2000 W. Energy: $E = 7.2$ MJ = 7,200,000 J
$E = 7.2$ MJ = 7.2 MJ × (1 kWh / 3.6 MJ) = 2 kWh. $t = E/P = 2\text{ kWh} / 2\text{ kW} = 1$ hour. Same answer.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Time to transfer given energy at given power: $t = E/P$. Energy (J) = Power (W) × time (s).

worked_examples.title: Power from Force and Velocity
worked_examples.problem: A train moves at constant 40 m/s while the engine exerts 25,000 N force to overcome resistance. What power does the engine deliver?

step_by_step.explanation: Force: $F = 25,000$ N (in direction of motion). Velocity: $v = 40$ m/s (constant, same direction as force)
Engine delivers 1 MW (megawatt) of power to maintain constant speed against resistance. This power continuously converts to heat via friction/air resistance.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Power at constant velocity: $P = Fv$. Force to overcome resistance × velocity = power needed.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Power Outputs
worked_examples.problem: Person A climbs 100 stairs (vertical rise 20 m) in 30 s. Person B climbs same stairs in 45 s. Both have mass 70 kg. Compare their power outputs.

step_by_step.explanation: Lift body weight to height 20 m: $W = mgh = 70 × 9.8 × 20 = 13,720$ J

Person A: 457 W (faster climb, higher power). Person B: 305 W (slower climb, lower power). Ratio: $P_A / P_B = 457/305 \approx 1.5$. Person A has 50% more power output. Same work, but A does it in 2/3 the time → 1.5× power.

worked_examples.final_answer: Person A: ~457 W. Person B: ~305 W. A has 50% higher power output (faster).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Same work, different times → different powers. Faster completion requires higher power: $P = W/t$.

worked_examples.title: Power and Energy Consumption
worked_examples.problem: A 1500 W microwave runs for 4 minutes. How much energy does it consume? What does this cost at $0.12 per kWh?
worked_examples.concept_applied: Energy consumption: $E = Pt$. Electricity cost = energy (kWh) × rate ($/kWh). High power × short time can still be low energy (and cheap).

sections.introduction: Power appears throughout physics and engineering—from human muscles to power plants, from vehicle engines to electrical appliances.

categories.description: Humans can produce varying power outputs depending on activity and duration.

examples.explanation: Peak power (short bursts, seconds): Trained athletes ~2000 W (sprinting, jumping). Untrained ~500-1000 W. Sustained power (minutes to hours): Trained athletes ~300-400 W (cycling, rowing). Untrained ~100-200 W. Long duration (hours): ~75-100 W (hiking, slow cycling). Power output limited by: Muscle strength (peak), Cardiovascular oxygen delivery (sustained), Energy stores (long duration). Power decreases as duration increases—can't maintain peak power for long.

Typical adult (70 kg) climbing stairs at normal pace: Vertical speed ~0.5 m/s. Power: $P = \frac{mgh}{t} = mg \cdot \frac{h}{t} = mgv_{\text{vertical}} = 70 × 9.8 × 0.5 ≈ 340$ W. Running up stairs (1 m/s vertical): Power ~700 W (more than double—quadratic relationship between speed and power for overcoming drag/friction, but linear for lifting).

Professional cyclist: Can sustain ~400 W for hour (time trial), ~250 W for 4-5 hours (road race). Recreational cyclist: ~150-200 W sustained. Power goes to: Overcoming air resistance (dominant at high speeds—increases with $v^3$), Rolling resistance (tires), Drivetrain friction, Climbing (if hills). At high speeds (>30 km/h), most power fighting air resistance.

Sprinting: High power output determines acceleration and top speed. Power = force × velocity. Stronger push (force) + faster movement (velocity) = more power. Endurance: Sustainable power determines pace. Higher sustained power = faster marathon time, longer cycling distance. Power-to-weight ratio critical in climbing sports (cycling uphill, running)—more power per kg body mass = faster climbing.

categories.description: Engines rated by maximum power output—determines performance.

examples.explanation: Typical ratings: Small car: 75-100 kW (100-135 hp). Midsize car: 120-180 kW (160-240 hp). Sports car: 300-600 kW (400-800 hp). Power determines: Acceleration (how quickly can do work to increase KE), Top speed (limited by power needed to overcome air resistance at high speeds: $P \propto v^3$), Towing capacity (power needed to accelerate heavier loads). Why horsepower outdated: 1 hp ≈ 746 W. Defined historically (power of horse). Kilowatts more logical (SI unit), but hp persists in automotive culture.

Air resistance force: $F_d \propto v^2$ (drag increases with speed squared). Power to overcome drag: $P = F_d \cdot v \propto v^2 \cdot v = v^3$ (cubic relationship). To double top speed: Need 8× power (2³ = 8). This is why: Minor speed increases at high speeds require large power increases. Top speed limited by maximum engine power. Example: Car with 100 kW engine might have top speed 180 km/h. To reach 220 km/h (22% faster): Need ~100 × (220/180)³ ≈ 183 kW (83% more power).

Electric motors: Very high efficiency (~90%), deliver maximum torque (rotational force) from standstill, instant power response. Gasoline engines: Lower efficiency (~25-30%), torque varies with RPM, power delivery less immediate. Electric vehicles: Often higher power-to-weight, better acceleration despite similar or lower peak power rating. Example: Electric car with 250 kW might accelerate faster than gas car with 300 kW (efficiency, torque curve advantages).

categories.description: Electrical devices consume power; ratings indicate energy usage rate.

examples.explanation: Common wattages: LED bulb: 10-15 W (replaces 60-100 W incandescent). Phone charger: 5-20 W. Laptop: 50-100 W. Microwave: 1000-1500 W. Electric heater: 1500-2000 W. Air conditioner: 1000-5000 W. Electric car charger: 7000-22,000 W (home), up to 350,000 W (fast charging). Higher wattage = faster energy consumption. Running 1500 W heater for 1 hour uses 1500 Wh = 1.5 kWh of energy.

Electric bill based on energy (kWh), not power: Energy = Power × Time. Bill charges per kWh (typically $0.10-$0.30/kWh depending on location). Example: 100 W bulb for 10 hours daily, 30 days: Energy per month = 100 W × (10 hr/day) × 30 days = 30,000 Wh = 30 kWh. Cost = 30 kWh × $0.12/kWh = $3.60/month. High-power devices cost more if run longer. Short usage of high power can be cheap (microwave: 1500 W for 5 min = 1.5 × 5/60 = 0.125 kWh ≈ 1.5 cents).

AC (alternating current) power more complex than DC: Real power (watts): Actual energy transfer rate. Reactive power (VARs): Power oscillating in reactive components (capacitors, inductors), doesn't do net work. Apparent power (VA): Product of voltage and current. Power factor = Real power / Apparent power. Unity (1.0) is ideal—all power does work. Low power factor (<0.9): Wasted energy in reactive oscillations, utilities may charge extra. This is why large industrial users need power factor correction.

categories.description: Large-scale power generation measured in megawatts and gigawatts.

examples.explanation: Small renewable: Solar panel ~300 W, Home solar array ~5-10 kW, Small wind turbine ~10-100 kW. Medium: Large wind turbine ~2-5 MW, Small hydro plant ~10-100 MW. Large: Coal/gas plant ~500-1000 MW, Nuclear plant ~1000-1600 MW (1-1.6 GW). Largest: Three Gorges Dam (hydro) ~22,500 MW (22.5 GW) capacity. Power plant output must match grid demand constantly. Too little → brownouts. Too much → waste (can't store easily). Grid management balances generation and consumption in real-time.

Base load: Minimum continuous power demand (night, constant needs). Supplied by: Nuclear, coal, large hydro (steady, economical at constant output, slow to adjust). Peak load: Extra demand during high-usage times (daytime, heat waves). Supplied by: Natural gas turbines (fast start-up), hydro (adjustable), batteries/storage (emerging). Peak power more expensive—must build extra capacity used only occasionally. Example: City base load 500 MW (constant), peaks to 900 MW (hot afternoons). Need 900 MW capacity, but only ~500 MW average—extra 400 MW sits idle most of time, expensive.

Solar/wind power varies with weather: Solar: Zero at night, variable with clouds, peaks midday. Wind: Varies with wind speed (power ∝ wind speed³). Creates grid challenges: Must have backup when renewables low. Energy storage (batteries, pumped hydro) smooths variations. Grid integration requires: Forecasting (predict renewable output), Fast-responding backup (gas turbines), Storage (batteries, other), Demand management (shift usage to match supply). As renewables grow, power management becomes more complex and important.

categories.description: Natural processes involve power—energy transfer rates in physical and biological systems.

examples.explanation: Solar constant: ~1360 W/m² at top of atmosphere (power per area from Sun). Earth's cross-section intercepts: π × (Earth radius)² ≈ 1.27 × 10¹⁴ m² of sunlight. Total solar power intercepted: ~1.7 × 10¹⁷ W (170 petawatts). Vastly exceeds human energy use (~18 TW globally, ~0.01% of solar input). About 30% reflected, 70% absorbed (heats Earth, drives weather, photosynthesis). Available solar energy enormous—challenge is capture and storage, not availability.

Global photosynthesis: Plants capture ~100-120 TW of solar power (store as chemical PE in biomass). About ~0.06% of solar input to Earth—very inefficient but vast scale. Human energy use (~18 TW) is ~15-20% of photosynthesis power. All fossil fuels from ancient stored photosynthesis—we're using geological energy savings.

Earth's internal heat flow: ~44 TW from core to surface (radioactive decay, primordial heat). Mostly diffuse, but concentrated at volcanic zones, hot springs. Geothermal plants tap this: ~15 GW worldwide currently (tiny fraction of potential). Sustainable: Earth's heat replenishes faster than we can extract in most locations.

image.caption: Power scales: Human ~100-500 W sustained. Car ~100-300 kW. Power plant ~500-1000 MW. Sun on Earth ~170 PW.

sections.introduction: Real systems are not 100% efficient—some input energy becomes waste heat. Understanding efficiency and power consumption is crucial for energy management.

key_concept.definition: Efficiency is the ratio of useful output energy (or power) to total input energy (or power): $\eta = \frac{E_{\text{out}}}{E_{\text{in}}} = \frac{P_{\text{out}}}{P_{\text{in}}}$ (often expressed as percentage). Efficiency always less than 100% (usually much less) due to friction, heat losses, other dissipative processes.
key_concept.context: No real machine or process is perfectly efficient. Some energy always becomes unusable heat. High efficiency means more useful output for given input (less waste). Improving efficiency saves energy and money.

principles.statement: Efficiency = (Useful output) / (Total input). Can be expressed for energy or power (same ratio): $\eta = \frac{E_{\text{useful}}}{E_{\text{input}}} × 100\%$ or $\eta = \frac{P_{\text{useful}}}{P_{\text{input}}} × 100\%$. Wasted energy = Input - Output = Input × (1 - η).
principles.application: Calculate efficiency from input/output measurements. Find wasted energy.
principles.example: Motor with 1000 W input, 700 W mechanical output: $\eta = 700/1000 = 0.7 = 70\%$ efficient. Wasted: 1000 - 700 = 300 W (becomes heat in motor windings, friction).

principles.statement: Common efficiencies: Electric motors: 85-95% (excellent). LED lights: 40-50%. Fluorescent lights: 20-30%. Incandescent bulbs: 5% (terrible—95% heat). Gasoline engines: 25-30%. Diesel engines: 30-40%. Power plants (fossil/nuclear): 33-40%. Hydroelectric: 85-90%. Solar panels: 15-22%. Human muscles: 20-25%. Battery charge/discharge: 80-95%.
principles.application: Use typical values to estimate waste in systems. Choose high-efficiency devices to save energy.
principles.example: Incandescent vs LED for same light output (10 W light): Incandescent: Need 100 W input (10% light, 90% heat). LED: Need 20 W input (50% light, 50% heat). LED uses 1/5 the energy for same light—huge savings over lifetime.

principles.statement: Total energy cost = Power × Time × Rate. Higher power or longer time → higher cost. High efficiency → lower power needed for same output → lower cost.
principles.application: Calculate operating costs for devices. Compare efficiency to find savings.
principles.example: Air conditioner cooling room: Old unit: 3000 W input, 60% efficient → 1800 W cooling. New unit: 1800 W input, 90% efficient → 1620 W cooling (same). Run 8 hr/day, 90 days (summer), electricity $0.12/kWh: Old: 3 kW × 8 × 90 = 2160 kWh × $0.12 = $259. New: 1.8 kW × 8 × 90 = 1296 kWh × $0.12 = $155. Save $104/summer (40% reduction) from efficiency improvement.

principles.statement: Thermodynamic limits (beyond scope here, but important): Heat engines (car, power plant) fundamentally limited by temperature difference—can never be 100% efficient (2nd law of thermodynamics). Theoretical maximum for heat engine: Carnot efficiency $\eta_{\text{max}} = 1 - T_{\text{cold}}/T_{\text{hot}}$ (temperatures in Kelvin). Practical engines much below this limit. Electric devices (motors, LEDs) can approach high efficiency (90%+) because not limited by thermodynamics—but friction, resistance still cause losses.
principles.application: Heat engines always waste significant energy. Electric systems can be much more efficient.
principles.example: Power plant: Hot steam ~800 K, cooling water ~300 K. Carnot maximum: $1 - 300/800 = 62.5\%$. Actual: ~40% (lost to friction, non-ideal processes, can't reach Carnot limit). Electric motor: Theoretical limit near 100%, practical ~90-95% (small resistive and friction losses). This is why electric vehicles more efficient than gasoline (electric motor ~90% vs engine ~25%).

worked_examples.title: Calculating Efficiency
worked_examples.problem: A motor draws 2400 W of electrical power and delivers 1900 W of mechanical power. Find: (a) efficiency, (b) power wasted as heat.

step_by_step.explanation: Motor is ~79% efficient (pretty good). 500 W (21% of input) becomes heat—motor will warm during operation. Must dissipate this heat via cooling.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Efficiency: useful output / total input. Waste = input - output. Most lost energy becomes heat.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Energy Costs
worked_examples.problem: Compare costs of incandescent (100 W, 5% efficient) vs LED (15 W, 50% efficient) for same light output over 10,000 hours at $0.12/kWh.

step_by_step.explanation: Savings: $120 - 18 = \$102$ over 10,000 hours (about 1 year of typical use, 24/7). LED uses 1/6.7 the energy (15W vs 100W). 10× better efficiency (50% vs 5%) plus lower power → huge savings.
LED costs ~$5 more initially. Payback time: $5 / ($120 - $18) × 10,000 hours ≈ 490 hours ≈ 20 days continuous use. After 3 weeks, LED has paid for itself—rest is pure savings.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Higher efficiency → lower power for same output → lower energy consumption → lower cost. Efficiency improvements pay for themselves quickly.

worked_examples.title: Engine Power and Efficiency
worked_examples.problem: A car engine is 28% efficient. At highway speed, it produces 45 kW of mechanical power to overcome air resistance and friction. (a) How much fuel power is consumed? (b) How much power is wasted as heat?

step_by_step.explanation: Engine burns fuel at rate providing 161 kW. Only 45 kW (28%) goes to moving car. 116 kW (72%) becomes waste heat (exhaust, coolant, radiation). This is why engines need: Large radiators (dissipate heat), Exhaust systems (vent hot gases), Cooling fans. Most fuel energy wasted—inherent to heat engines.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Fuel power = 161 kW, (b) Waste heat = 116 kW (72% of input)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Low efficiency → much higher input than output. Heat engines waste majority of fuel energy as heat (thermodynamic limit).

image.alt: Energy flow diagrams showing high efficiency (90% output, 10% waste) vs low efficiency (30% output, 70% waste)
image.caption: Efficiency: High (90%—most input becomes output, little waste). Low (30%—most input wasted as heat). Efficiency = Output/Input.

summary: Power is the rate of doing work or transferring energy: $P = W/t$ (work per time) or $P = E/t$ (energy per time) where $t$ is time interval (s). SI unit: watt (W) = joule/second (J/s). Common multiples: kilowatt (kW = 1000 W), megawatt (MW = 10⁶ W), gigawatt (GW = 10⁹ W). Alternative formula for constant force and velocity: $P = Fv$ (force × velocity in force direction). Higher force or velocity → higher power. Power distinguishes fast from slow energy transfer: Same work done quickly requires high power, slowly requires low power. Two machines doing same work but different times have different power outputs. Human power: Peak ~500-2000 W (seconds), sustained ~100-400 W (hours), long duration ~75-100 W. Athletes have higher power outputs. Power-to-weight ratio important for climbing, acceleration. Vehicles: Car engines 75-300 kW typical. Power determines acceleration and top speed. Top speed limited by power needed to overcome air resistance (power ∝ $v^3$ for drag). Electric motors more efficient (~90%) than gasoline engines (~25-30%). Electrical power: Appliances rated in watts (power consumption rate). Energy consumption = power × time. Electricity billed in kilowatt-hours (kWh): 1 kWh = 1000 W for 1 hour = 3.6 MJ. Higher wattage devices use energy faster but not necessarily more total (depends on usage time). Power plants: Range from kilowatts (small renewables) to gigawatts (large nuclear/hydro plants). Grid must balance generation and consumption constantly. Base load (constant) vs peak load (high-demand times) requires different generation strategies. Efficiency: Ratio of useful output to total input: $\eta = P_{\text{out}}/P_{\text{in}}$ (or same for energy). Always <100% due to friction, heat losses, thermodynamic limits. Typical efficiencies: Electric motors 85-95% (excellent), LEDs 40-50%, incandescent bulbs 5% (terrible), gasoline engines 25-30%, power plants 33-40%. Waste energy = input × (1 - efficiency), usually becomes heat. Higher efficiency → less input needed for same output → lower energy costs. LED vs incandescent: 1/5 the power for same light due to 10× better efficiency. Power consumption and cost: Energy cost = power × time × electricity rate ($/kWh). High-power devices expensive to run if used long. Efficiency improvements save money—often pay for themselves quickly through reduced operating costs. Understanding power essential for: Rating machines and engines, calculating energy consumption and costs, comparing device efficiency, managing electrical grids, analyzing athletic performance. Power connects work/energy (quantities in joules) to time (how fast processes occur), providing complete picture of energy systems.
